informal_statement: 20th Swedish 1980 Problem 4 The functions f and g are positive and continuous. f is increasing and g is decreasing. Show that ∫ 0 1 f(x) g(x) dx ≤ ∫ 0 1 f(x) g(1-x) dx.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Topology Filter Real Complex TopologicalSpace Finset
open scoped BigOperators

/- 20th Swedish 1980 Problem 4 The functions f and g are positive and continuous. f is increasing and g is decreasing. Show that ∫ 0 1 f(x) g(x) dx ≤ ∫ 0 1 f(x) g(1-x) dx. -/
theorem calculus_145237
  (f g : ℝ → ℝ)
  (hf : Continuous f)
  (hg : Continuous g)
  (hf' : ∀ x, 0 < f x)
  (hg' : ∀ x, 0 < g x)
  (hf'' : ∀ x y, x < y → f x < f y)
  (hg'' : ∀ x y, x < y → g x > g y) :
  ∫ x in (0)..1, f x * g x ≤ ∫ x in (0)..1, f x * g (1 - x) :=

soln_description:
Solution 1 First prove a lemma
Lemma $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{n}, b_{1}, b_{2}, \cdots, b_{n} \in \mathbf{R}_{+}$, $n \geqslant 2, a_{i}>b_{i}(1 \leqslant i \leqslant n)$. Then
$\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left(a_{i}-b_{i}\right) \leqslant\left(\sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n} a_{i}}-\sqrt[n]{\prod_{i=1}^{n} b_{i}}\right)^{n}$.
Proof (1) Prove the case when $n=2^{k}\left(k \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$. Use mathematical induction on $k$.
When $k=1$,
$\left(a_{1}-b_{1}\right)\left(a_{2}-b_{2}\right) \leqslant\left(\sqrt{a_{1} a_{2}}-\sqrt{b_{1} b_{2}}\right)^{2}$
$\Leftrightarrow a_{1} b_{2}+a_{2} b_{1}-2 \sqrt{a_{1} b_{2} a_{2} b_{1}} \geqslant 0$
$\Leftrightarrow\left(\sqrt{a_{1} b_{2}}-\sqrt{a_{2} b_{1}}\right)^{2} \geqslant 0$.
The proposition holds.
Assume the proposition holds when $k=s$,
Then when $k=s+1$,
$\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s+1}}\left(a_{i}-b_{i}\right)$
$=\left[\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s}}\left(a_{i}-b_{i}\right)\right]\left[\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s}}\left(a_{i+2^{s}}-b_{i+2^{s}}\right)\right]$
$\leqslant\left[\left(\sqrt[2^{s}]{\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s}} a_{i}}-\sqrt[2^{s}]{\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s}} b_{i}}\right)\right.$
$\left.\left(\sqrt[2^{s}]{\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s}} a_{i+2^{s}}}-\sqrt[2^{s}]{\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s}} b_{i+2^{s}}}\right)\right]^{2^{s}}$
$\leqslant\left(\sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s+1}} a_{i}}-\sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{2^{s+1}} b_{i}}\right)^{2^{s+1}}$.
Thus, the proposition holds in this case.
(2) Prove: If the proposition holds when $n=r+1$,
then the proposition also holds when $n=r$
$\left(r \geqslant 2, r \in \mathbf{Z}_{+}\right)$.
Let $A=\sqrt[r]{\prod_{i=1}^{r} a_{i}}, B=\sqrt[r]{\prod_{i=1}^{r} b_{i}}$,
$a_{i}^{*}=a_{i}, b_{i}^{*}=b_{i}(1 \leqslant i \leqslant r)$,
$a_{r+1}=A, b_{r+1}=B$.
Then $A>B$.
By the induction hypothesis,
$\prod_{i=1}^{r+1}\left(a_{i}^{*}-b_{i}^{*}\right)$
$\leqslant\left(\sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{r+1} a_{i}^{*}}-\sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{r+1} b_{i}^{*}}\right)^{r+1}$
$=(A-B)^{r+1}$
$\Rightarrow \prod_{i=1}^{r}\left(a_{i}-b_{i}\right)=\frac{\prod_{i=1}^{r+1}\left(a_{i}^{*}-b_{i}^{*}\right)}{A-B} \leqslant(A-B)^{r}$.
In summary, the lemma is proved.
For any $i(1 \leqslant i \leqslant 2015)$, by the given conditions,
$9 a_{i}>11 a_{i+1}^{2} \geqslant 9 a_{i+1}^{2} \geqslant 0 \Rightarrow a_{i}-a_{i+1}^{2}>0$
If $a_{2016}-a_{1}^{2} \leqslant 0$, then
$M=\prod_{i=2010}^{2016}\left(a_{i}-a_{i+1}^{2}\right) \leqslant 0\left(a_{2017}=a_{1}\right)$.
Therefore, we only need to consider the case $a_{2016}-a_{1}^{2}>0$,
in which case,
$\prod_{i=1}^{2016} a_{i}>\prod_{i=1}^{2016} a_{i+1}^{2} \Rightarrow S=\sqrt{\prod_{i=1}^{2016} a_{i}}$.
If $a_{2016}-a_{1}^{2} \leqslant 0$, then $P \leqslant 0$.
Below, consider the case $a_{2016}-a_{1}^{2}>0$.
Let $m_{i}=\frac{a_{i}}{a_{i+1}^{2}}(i=1,2, \cdots, 2015)$,
$m_{2016}=\frac{a_{2016}}{a_{1}^{2}}$,

Then, $\prod_{i=1}^{2016} m_{i}=\prod_{i=1}^{2016} \frac{1}{a_{i}}$.
Also, $m_{i}>\frac{11}{9}(i=1,2, \cdots, 2015)$, so
$P=\prod_{i=1}^{2016}\left[\left(m_{i}-1\right) a_{i}^{2}\right]$
$=\left[\prod_{i=1}^{2016}\left(m_{i}-1\right)\right]\left(\prod_{i=1}^{2016} a_{i}^{2}\right)$
$=\left[\prod_{i=1}^{2016}\left(m_{i}-1\right)\right]\left(\prod_{i=1}^{2016} \frac{1}{m_{i}^{2}}\right)$
$=\prod_{i=1}^{2016} \frac{m_{i}-1}{m_{i}^{2}}$.
Notice that,
$\frac{m_{i}-1}{m_{i}^{2}}=-\left(\frac{1}{m_{i}}-\frac{1}{2}\right)^{2}+\frac{1}{4} \leqslant \frac{1}{4}$.
Thus, $P=\prod_{i=1}^{2016} \frac{m_{i}-1}{m_{i}^{2}} \leqslant \frac{1}{4^{2016}}$.
The equality holds if and only if
$m_{i}=2(i=1,2, \cdots, 2016)$,

which means $a_{i}=2 a_{i+1}^{2}(i=1,2, \cdots, 2015), a_{2016}=2 a_{1}^{2}$.
Solving this, we get $a_{i}=\frac{1}{2}(i=1,2, \cdots, 2016)$.
Upon verification, this satisfies the given inequalities, indicating that the equality can hold.
In summary, the maximum value sought is $\frac{1}{4^{2016}}$.
informal_statement:
The first question: Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{2016}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
9 a_{i}>11 a_{i+1}^{2}(i=1,2, \cdots, 2015) \text {. Find } \\
\quad\left(a_{1}-a_{2}^{2}\right)\left(a_{2}-a_{3}^{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{2015}-a_{2016}^{2}\right)\left(a_{2016}-a_{1}^{2}\right)
\end{array}
$$

the maximum value.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- The first question: Let real numbers $a_{1}, a_{2}, \cdots, a_{2016}$ satisfy
$$
\begin{array}{l}
9 a_{i}>11 a_{i+1}^{2}(i=1,2, \cdots, 2015) \text {. Find } \\
\quad\left(a_{1}-a_{2}^{2}\right)\left(a_{2}-a_{3}^{2}\right) \cdots\left(a_{2015}-a_{2016}^{2}\right)\left(a_{2016}-a_{1}^{2}\right)
\end{array}
$$

the maximum value. -/
theorem algebra_117558 (a : Fin 2016 → ℝ) (h : ∀ i, 9 * a i > 11 * (a (i + 1)) ^ 2) :
    (∏ i, a i - (a (i + 1)) ^ 2) ≤ 1 / 4 ^ 2016 := by

soln_description:
$$\begin{array}{l}
\text { 14. Let } x=\sqrt{a-1}, y=\sqrt{b-1}, z=\sqrt{c-1}, \text { then } \sqrt{a-1}+\sqrt{b-1}+\sqrt{c-1} \leqslant \\
\sqrt{(a b+1) c} \Leftrightarrow x+y+z \leqslant \sqrt{\left[\left(1+x^{2}\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right)+1\right]\left(1+z^{2}\right)} \Leftrightarrow(x+y+z)^{2} \leqslant \\
{\left[\left(1+x^{2}\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right)+1\right]\left(1+z^{2}\right) \Leftrightarrow\left(1+x^{2}\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right) z^{2}-2(x+y) z+x^{2} y^{2}-} \\
2 x y+2 \geqslant 0 \text {, the left side is a quadratic trinomial in } z \text {, so we only need to prove } \Delta=[2(x+y)]^{2}-4(1+ \\
\left.x^{2}\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right)\left(x^{2} y^{2}-2 x y+2\right) \leqslant 0 .
\end{array}$$

By the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality, we have
$$\left(1+x^{2}\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right)=\left(x^{2}+1\right)\left(1+y^{2}\right) \geqslant(x+y)^{2}$$

And
$$x^{2} y^{2}-2 x y+2=(x y-1)^{2}+1 \geqslant 1$$

Therefore, $\Delta \leqslant 0$. (Or write $\Delta$ as $-4(x y-1)^{2}\left(2+x^{2} y^{2}+x^{2}+y^{2}\right)$ ).
informal_statement: 14. Given $a, b, c \geqslant 1$, prove: $\sqrt{a-1}+\sqrt{b-1}+\sqrt{c-1} \leqslant \sqrt{(a b+1) c}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 14. Given $a, b, c \geqslant 1$, prove: $\sqrt{a-1}+\sqrt{b-1}+\sqrt{c-1} \leqslant \sqrt{(a b+1) c}$. -/
theorem inequalities_602081 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 1 ≤ a) (hb : 1 ≤ b) (hc : 1 ≤ c) :
    sqrt (a - 1) + sqrt (b - 1) + sqrt (c - 1) ≤ sqrt ((a * b + 1) * c) := by

soln_description:
Since Igor passed an integer number of circles, he met the first pastry at the moment of approaching the table. In addition, the sequence of eating pastries will not change if we remove the requirement of "equal intervals". If there were four pastries, Igor would have walked exactly five circles (see the figure).

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_05_06_9c89379ec21d997cc715g-15.jpg?height=703&width=786&top_left_y=2127&top_left_x=636)

Let the number of pastries on the table be divisible by three. Then, in the first circle, Igor eats every third pastry and returns to the initial position. Thus, after one circle, the number of pastries becomes $2 / 3$ of the number that was on the table. Therefore, if there were six pastries, Igor would have walked exactly six circles, and if there were nine pastries, Igor would have walked exactly seven circles.

If there are more than nine pastries, then Igor will travel some distance before the number of pastries is exactly nine, reach the nearest pastry, and then make exactly seven circles. Thus, in total, he has walked more than seven circles.

If there are fewer than nine pastries, and the number of circles is also seven, then, as shown above, we prove that for nine pastries, the number of circles is more than seven. Contradiction.

## Answer

9.
informal_statement:
Kostrikina I.A.

At a round table, pastries are placed at equal intervals. Igor walks around the table and eats every third pastry he encounters (each pastry can be encountered several times). When there were no pastries left on the table, he noticed that the last pastry he took was the first one he encountered, and he had walked exactly seven rounds around the table. How many pastries were there?
informal_proof:
We are asked to prove that for any positive natural number \( n \), if \( n \) satisfies the equation \( n \cdot 3 = 7 \cdot (n - 1) \), then \( n \) must be equal to \( 9 \).

We begin by considering the possible values of \( n \) as a natural number.

**Case 1: \( n = 0 \)**
If \( n \) were \( 0 \), the hypothesis \( n > 0 \) would not be satisfied. Therefore, this case does not meet the conditions of the theorem.

**Case 2: \( n > 0 \)**
In this case, \( n \) is a positive natural number. We are given the equation:
\[ n \cdot 3 = 7 \cdot (n - 1) \]
We can simplify this equation using basic properties of arithmetic for natural numbers. The expression \( n - 1 \) is well-defined since \( n > 0 \). Applying the distributive property and properties of subtraction, the equation becomes:
\[ 3n = 7n - 7 \]
To solve for \( n \), we rearrange the terms:
\[ 7 = 7n - 3n \]
\[ 7 = 4n \]
This simplified equation, \( 4n = 7 \), has no solution for \( n \) within the set of natural numbers, as \( n \) would need to be \( \frac{7}{4} \), which is not an integer.

The theorem requires us to show that if \( n > 0 \) and \( 4n = 7 \), then \( n = 9 \). Since there are no natural numbers \( n \) that can satisfy the condition \( 4n = 7 \), the premise "\( n > 0 \) and \( 4n = 7 \)" is false. In logic, a statement with a false premise is always true, regardless of the conclusion. This is known as a vacuously true statement. Therefore, the implication that \( n = 9 \) holds true.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Kostrikina I.A.

At a round table, pastries are placed at equal intervals. Igor walks around the table and eats every third pastry he encounters (each pastry can be encountered several times). When there were no pastries left on the table, he noticed that the last pastry he took was the first one he encountered, and he had walked exactly seven rounds around the table. How many pastries were there? -/
theorem number_theory_213083 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) (h : n * 3 = 7 * (n - 1)) :
    n = 9 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem number_theory_213083 {n : ℕ} (hn : n > 0) (h : n * 3 = 7 * (n - 1)) :
    n = 9 := by
  cases n with
  | zero =>
    linarith
  | succ n =>
    simp [Nat.mul_add, Nat.mul_assoc, Nat.sub_add_cancel] at h ⊢
    all_goals
      omega

soln_description:
Given the conditions, we have $b(a z+c x) + c(b x+a y) - a(c y+b z) = b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}$, which simplifies to $2 b c x = b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}$. Therefore, $x = \frac{b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}}{2 b c}$,

Similarly, $y = \frac{c^{2} + a^{2} - b^{2}}{2 c a}$, and $z = \frac{a^{2} + b^{2} - c^{2}}{2 a b}$.
Thus,
$$\begin{array}{l}
f(x, y, z) = \sum \frac{x^{2}}{1 + x} \\
= \sum \frac{\left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)^{2}}{4 b^{2} c^{2} + 2 b c \left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)} \\
\geqslant \sum \frac{\left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)^{2}}{4 b^{2} c^{2} + \left(b^{2} + c^{2}\right) \left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)} \\
\geqslant \frac{\left[\sum \left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)\right]^{2}}{4 \sum b^{2} c^{2} + \sum \left(b^{2} + c^{2}\right) \left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)} \\
= \frac{\left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)^{2}}{4 \sum b^{2} c^{2} + \sum \left(b^{2} + c^{2}\right) \left(b^{2} + c^{2} + a^{2}\right) - 2 \sum \left(b^{2} + c^{2}\right) a^{2}} \\
\Rightarrow \frac{\left(b^{2} + c^{2} - a^{2}\right)^{2}}{4 \sum b^{2} c^{2} + 2 \left(b^{2} + c^{2} + a^{2}\right)^{2} - 4 \sum b^{2} c^{2}} \\
= \frac{1}{2}
\end{array}$$

The right side of inequality (5) is derived from the equivalent form of the Cauchy-Schwarz inequality (2), and equality in (5) holds if and only if $a = b = c$, i.e., $x = y = z = \frac{1}{2}$. At this point, equality in (6) also holds, so when $x = y = z = \frac{1}{2}$, $f(x, y, z)$ achieves its minimum value of $\frac{1}{2}$.
informal_statement: Example 4—(2005 National High School Mathematics League Additional Question 2) Let positive numbers $a, b, c, x, y, z$ satisfy $c y + b z = a, a z + c x = b, b x + a y = c$, find the minimum value of the function $f(x, y, z) = \frac{x^{2}}{1+x} + \frac{y^{2}}{1+y} + \frac{z^{2}}{1+z}$.

3. Answer: $\frac{3 \pm \sqrt{5}}{2}$.

Let $y=x^{2}+1$, the equation is $\frac{1}{y}+\frac{y}{x^{2}}=\frac{10}{3 x}$. Clearing the denominators: $3 x^{2}-10 x y+3 y^{2}=0$.
We get $y_{1}=3 x, y_{2}=\frac{1}{3} x$.
From $y=3 x, x^{2}-1=3 x$, we get $x=\frac{3 \pm}{2}$.
From $y=\frac{1}{3} x, x^{2}+1=\frac{x}{3}, \Delta<0$ no real roots.

Prove that  $$ \frac{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}\left[1-\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\right]}{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(1-a_{1}\right)\left(1-a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(1-a_{n}\right)} \leq \frac{1}{n^{n+1}} . $$

Prove that  $$ \frac{a_{1} a_{2} \cdots a_{n}\left[1-\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\right]}{\left(a_{1}+a_{2}+\cdots+a_{n}\right)\left(1-a_{1}\right)\left(1-a_{2}\right) \cdots\left(1-a_{n}\right)} \leq \frac{1}{n^{n+1}} . $$ -/

$7.3 \sqrt{3}$.
Let $z=a+b$ i. Then $a^{2}+b^{2}=1$.
Thus $\left|z^{3}-3 z-2\right|=|z+1|^{2}|z-2|$
$=2(a+1) \sqrt{5-4 a}$
$=\sqrt{(2 a+2)(2 a+2)(5-4 a)} \leqslant 3 \sqrt{3}$.
When $a=\frac{1}{2}, b= \pm \frac{\sqrt{2}}{2}$, the equality holds.

soln_description:
7.1 Here all powers can be reduced to the same base 5. We have:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \sqrt{5}=5^{\frac{1}{2}}, 0.2^{\frac{1}{2 x}}=\left(\frac{1}{5}\right)^{\frac{1}{2 x}}=5^{-\frac{1}{2 x}} \\
& 0.04^{1-x}=\left(\frac{1}{25}\right)^{1-x}=5^{-2(1-x)}
\end{aligned}
$$

Then the equation will take the form

$$
5^{\frac{1}{2}} \cdot 5^{-\frac{1}{2 x}}-5^{-2(1-x)}=0, \text { or } 5^{\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2 x}}=5^{-2(1-x)}
$$

According to the hint $1^{0}$, we transition to the equivalent equation

$$
\frac{1}{2}-\frac{1}{2 x}=-2(1-x)
$$

After transformations, we get

$\left\{\begin{array}{l}4 x^{2}-5 x+1=0, \\ x \neq 0,\end{array}\right.$

from which $x_{1}=1, x_{2}=\frac{1}{4}$.

Answer: $x_{1}=1, x_{2}=0.25$.

2. Determine $x, y, z \in \mathbb{R}$ that satisfy the relations: $\left\{\begin{array}{l}25 x^{2}+20 y^{2}+13 z^{2} \leq 1952 \\ 3 x y+6 y z+4 z x=488 \\ x+y+z=18\end{array}\right.$ Mihai Bodan, Cosmești, Teleorman
informal_statement:
2. Since $1952=4 \cdot 488$, using the first two relations of the system, we get:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \quad 25 x^{2}+20 y^{2}+13 z^{2} \leq 4 \cdot(3 x y+6 y z+4 z x) \Leftrightarrow 25 x^{2}+20 y^{2}+13 z^{2}-12 x y-24 y z-16 z x \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow\left(9 x^{2}-12 x y+4 y^{2}\right)+\left(16 y^{2}-24 y z+9 z^{2}\right)+\left(4 z^{2}-16 z x+16 x^{2}\right) \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(3 x-2 y)^{2}+(4 y-3 z)^{2}+(2 z-4 x)^{2} \leq 0 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

From here it follows that $\frac{x}{2}=\frac{y}{3}=\frac{z}{4}=k \Rightarrow x=2 k, y=3 k, z=4 k$. The third relation of the system becomes: $2 k+3 k+4 k=18$, so $k=\frac{18}{9}=2$ and $x=2 \cdot 2=4, y=3 \cdot 2=6, z=4 \cdot 2=8$.

(Note: There is a minor error in the original text where it states $k=\frac{18}{2}=9$. It should be $k=\frac{18}{9}=2$.)

$$

& \quad 25 x^{2}+20 y^{2}+13 z^{2} \leq 4 \cdot(3 x y+6 y z+4 z x) \Leftrightarrow 25 x^{2}+20 y^{2}+13 z^{2}-12 x y-24 y z-16 z x \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \quad \Leftrightarrow\left(9 x^{2}-12 x y+4 y^{2}\right)+\left(16 y^{2}-24 y z+9 z^{2}\right)+\left(4 z^{2}-16 z x+16 x^{2}\right) \leq 0 \Leftrightarrow \\
& \Leftrightarrow(3 x-2 y)^{2}+(4 y-3 z)^{2}+(2 z-4 x)^{2} \leq 0 \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots \ldots
\end{aligned}
$$

From here it follows that $\frac{x}{2}=\frac{y}{3}=\frac{z}{4}=k \Rightarrow x=2 k, y=3 k, z=4 k$. The third relation of the system becomes: $2 k+3 k+4 k=18$, so $k=\frac{18}{9}=2$ and $x=2 \cdot 2=4, y=3 \cdot 2=6, z=4 \cdot 2=8$.

(Note: There is a minor error in the original text where it states $k=\frac{18}{2}=9$. It should be $k=\frac{18}{9}=2$.) -/
theorem algebra_118506 {x y z : ℝ} (h1 : 25*x^2+20*y^2+13*z^2 ≤ 4*(3*x*y+6*y*z+4*z*x)) (h2 : 2*x+3*y+4*z=18) :
    x=4 ∧ y=6 ∧ z=8 := by

soln_description:

1. For every natural number \(n\): If \(n\) is composite, then \(2^{n}-1\) is not a prime number.

Proof: Let \(n=p q\) with natural numbers \(p, q>1\). Then, with \(x=2^{p}\), the number

\[
2^{n}-1=x^{q}-1=(x-1)\left(x^{q-1}+\ldots+x+1\right)
\]

is composite because \(x+1>1\) and \(x^{q-1}+\ldots+x+1 \geq x+1>1\). 2. For every natural number \(N>1\), none of the \(N-1\) numbers

\[
n \in\{N!+2 ; N!+3 ; \ldots ; N!+N\}
\]

is a prime number, because these numbers are each divisible by \(2,3, \ldots, N\) and are greater than the mentioned divisors. If one chooses an \(N>1\) with \(N>z+1\), then the segment of the sequence elements \(2^{n}-1\) formed with the numbers \(n\) from (1) has the length \(N-1>z\) and, due to 1., there is no prime number in this segment.
informal_statement:
\section*{Exercise 3A - 291043A}

Prove the following statement:

The sequence \((2 n-1)(n=1,2,3, \ldots)\) contains, for any arbitrary number \(z\), a segment whose length is greater than \(z\) and in which no prime number occurs.

Hint:

If \(\left(a_{n}\right)(n=1,2,3, \ldots)\) is a sequence and \(k \geq 1\) and \(m\) are natural numbers, then the \(k\)-tuple \(\left(a_{m+1}, a_{m+2}, \ldots, a_{m+k}\right)\) is called a segment of the sequence \(\left(a_{n}\right)\) and \(k\) is its length.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- \section*{Exercise 3A - 291043A}

Prove the following statement:

The sequence \((2 n-1)(n=1,2,3, \ldots)\) contains, for any arbitrary number \(z\), a segment whose length is greater than \(z\) and in which no prime number occurs.

Hint:

If \(\left(a_{n}\right)(n=1,2,3, \ldots)\) is a sequence and \(k \geq 1\) and \(m\) are natural numbers, then the \(k\)-tuple \(\left(a_{m+1}, a_{m+2}, \ldots, a_{m+k}\right)\) is called a segment of the sequence \(\left(a_{n}\right)\) and \(k\) is its length. -/
theorem number_theory_191317 (z : ℕ) :
    ∃ n, ∀ i ∈ Finset.Icc n (n + z), ¬Nat.Prime (2 * i - 1) := by

soln_description:
Solution by e_power_pi_times_i
Since the product of the first $n$ numbers in the sequence is $n^2$, the product of the first $n+1$ numbers in the sequence is $(n+1)^2$. Therefore the $n+1$th number in the sequence is $\frac{(n+1)^2}{n^2}$. Therefore the third and the fifth numbers are $\frac{9}{4}$ and $\frac{25}{16}$ respectively. The sum of those numbers is $\frac{36}{16}+\frac{25}{16} = \boxed{\textbf{(C) } \frac{61}{16}}$.
informal_statement:
In a certain sequence of numbers, the first number is $1$, and, for all $n\ge 2$, the product of the first $n$ numbers in the sequence is $n^2$. 
The sum of the third and the fifth numbers in the sequence is
$\textbf{(A) }\frac{25}{9}\qquad \textbf{(B) }\frac{31}{15}\qquad \textbf{(C) }\frac{61}{16}\qquad \textbf{(D) }\frac{576}{225}\qquad \textbf{(E) }34$
informal_proof:
Let $a$ be a sequence of real numbers satisfying the given conditions.
We are given that $a(0) = 1$.
We are also given that for any natural number $n \geq 2$, the product of the first $n$ terms of the sequence is $n^2$:
$$ \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} a(i) = n^2 \quad \text{for } n \geq 2 $$

We first determine the value of $a(1)$. Using the given product relation for $n=2$:
$$ \prod_{i=0}^{1} a(i) = 2^2 $$
$$ a(0) \cdot a(1) = 4 $$
Since $a(0) = 1$, we have $1 \cdot a(1) = 4$, which implies $a(1) = 4$.

Now, we derive a general formula for $a(k)$ for $k \geq 2$. For $n \geq 3$, the product relation states:
$$ \prod_{i=0}^{n-1} a(i) = n^2 $$
For $n \geq 3$, the term $n-1$ is at least 2, so we can also write the product relation for $n-1$:
$$ \prod_{i=0}^{n-2} a(i) = (n-1)^2 $$
Dividing these two equations, we obtain:
$$ \frac{\prod_{i=0}^{n-1} a(i)}{\prod_{i=0}^{n-2} a(i)} = \frac{n^2}{(n-1)^2} $$
The left side simplifies to $a(n-1)$. Thus, for $n \geq 3$:
$$ a(n-1) = \left(\frac{n}{n-1}\right)^2 $$
Let $k = n-1$. As $n$ ranges over $3, 4, 5, \ldots$, $k$ ranges over $2, 3, 4, \ldots$. Substituting $n = k+1$, we get:
$$ a(k) = \left(\frac{k+1}{k}\right)^2 \quad \text{for } k \geq 2 $$

We need to compute $a(2) + a(4)$.
Using the formula for $k=2$:
$$ a(2) = \left(\frac{2+1}{2}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{3}{2}\right)^2 = \frac{9}{4} $$
Using the formula for $k=4$:
$$ a(4) = \left(\frac{4+1}{4}\right)^2 = \left(\frac{5}{4}\right)^2 = \frac{25}{16} $$

Now we compute the sum:
$$ a(2) + a(4) = \frac{9}{4} + \frac{25}{16} $$
To sum these fractions, we find a common denominator, which is 16:
$$ \frac{9}{4} = \frac{9 \times 4}{4 \times 4} = \frac{36}{16} $$
Therefore, the sum is:
$$ \frac{36}{16} + \frac{25}{16} = \frac{36 + 25}{16} = \frac{61}{16} $$
The sum of the third and fifth numbers in the sequence is $\frac{61}{16}$.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- In a certain sequence of numbers, the first number is $1$, and, for all $n\ge 2$, the product of the first $n$ numbers in the sequence is $n^2$. 
The sum of the third and the fifth numbers in the sequence is
$\textbf{(A) }\frac{25}{9}\qquad \textbf{(B) }\frac{31}{15}\qquad \textbf{(C) }\frac{61}{16}\qquad \textbf{(D) }\frac{576}{225}\qquad \textbf{(E) }34$ -/
theorem algebra_93289 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : a 0 = 1)
    (h : ∀ n ≥ 2, ∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, a i = n ^ 2) :
    a 2 + a 4 = 61 / 16 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_93289 (a : ℕ → ℝ) (ha : a 0 = 1)
    (h : ∀ n ≥ 2, ∏ i ∈ Finset.range n, a i = n ^ 2) :
    a 2 + a 4 = 61 / 16 := by
  have ha1 : a 1 = 4 := by 
    have h2 := h 2 (by norm_num)
    simp [Finset.prod_range_succ, ha] at h2 
    nlinarith 
  have ha2 : a 2 = 9 / 4 := by 
    have h3 := h 3 (by norm_num)
    have h2 := h 2 (by norm_num)
    simp [Finset.prod_range_succ, ha, ha1] at h3 h2 
    nlinarith 
  have ha3 : a 3 = 16 / 9 := by 
    have h4 := h 4 (by norm_num)
    have h3 := h 3 (by norm_num)
    simp [Finset.prod_range_succ, ha, ha1, ha2] at h4 h3 
    nlinarith 
  have ha4 : a 4 = 25 / 16 := by 
    have h5 := h 5 (by norm_num)
    have h4 := h 4 (by norm_num)
    simp [Finset.prod_range_succ, ha, ha1, ha2, ha3] at h5 h4 
    nlinarith 
  rw [ha2, ha4]
  norm_num

soln_description:
By IAG we have: $a+b \geqslant 2 \sqrt{a b}, b+c \geqslant 2 \sqrt{b c}, c+a \geqslant 2 \sqrt{c a}$.

Since each term is positive, we can multiply the inequalities, which gives the desired result.
informal_statement: Show that for all positive real numbers $a, b, c$, we have: $(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \geqslant 8 a b c$
informal_proof:
We are given three positive real numbers $a, b,$ and $c$. Our goal is to prove the inequality $(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \ge 8abc$.

We start from the fact that the square of any real number is non-negative. Specifically, for any two real numbers $x$ and $y$, we have $(x-y)^2 \ge 0$. Expanding this, we get $x^2 - 2xy + y^2 \ge 0$, which implies $x^2 + y^2 \ge 2xy$.

Applying this principle to the pairs of variables $(a, b)$, $(b, c)$, and $(a, c)$:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item For $(a, b)$: $(a-b)^2 \ge 0 \implies a^2 + b^2 \ge 2ab$.
    \item For $(b, c)$: $(b-c)^2 \ge 0 \implies b^2 + c^2 \ge 2bc$.
    \item For $(a, c)$: $(a-c)^2 \ge 0 \implies a^2 + c^2 \ge 2ac$.
\end{enumerate}
Since $a, b, c$ are positive, $a, b, c$ are also positive. We can add terms to these inequalities to form squares of sums.
\begin{enumerate}
    \item Adding $2ab$ to both sides of $a^2 + b^2 \ge 2ab$, we get $a^2 + 2ab + b^2 \ge 2ab + 2ab$, which simplifies to $(a+b)^2 \ge 4ab$.
    \item Adding $2bc$ to both sides of $b^2 + c^2 \ge 2bc$, we get $b^2 + 2bc + c^2 \ge 2bc + 2bc$, which simplifies to $(b+c)^2 \ge 4bc$.
    \item Adding $2ac$ to both sides of $a^2 + c^2 \ge 2ac$, we get $a^2 + 2ac + c^2 \ge 2ac + 2ac$, which simplifies to $(a+c)^2 \ge 4ac$.
\end{enumerate}
Since $a, b, c$ are positive, the sums $a+b$, $b+c$, and $a+c$ are also positive. Therefore, we can take the square root of both sides of these inequalities:
\begin{enumerate}
    \item $\sqrt{(a+b)^2} \ge \sqrt{4ab} \implies a+b \ge 2\sqrt{ab}$.
    \item $\sqrt{(b+c)^2} \ge \sqrt{4bc} \implies b+c \ge 2\sqrt{bc}$.
    \item $\sqrt{(a+c)^2} \ge \sqrt{4ac} \implies a+c \ge 2\sqrt{ac}$.
\end{enumerate}
Now we have three inequalities: $a+b \ge 2\sqrt{ab}$, $b+c \ge 2\sqrt{bc}$, and $a+c \ge 2\sqrt{ac}$. Since all these terms are positive, we can multiply these three inequalities together:
$$ (a+b)(b+c)(a+c) \ge (2\sqrt{ab})(2\sqrt{bc})(2\sqrt{ac}) $$
$$ (a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \ge 8 \sqrt{a \cdot b \cdot b \cdot c \cdot a \cdot c} $$
$$ (a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \ge 8 \sqrt{a^2 b^2 c^2} $$
Since $a, b, c$ are positive real numbers, $\sqrt{a^2 b^2 c^2} = abc$. Thus, the inequality becomes:
$$ (a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \ge 8abc $$
This concludes the proof.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- Show that for all positive real numbers $a, b, c$, we have: $(a+b)(b+c)(c+a) \geqslant 8 a b c$ -/
theorem inequalities_110725 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + a) ≥ 8 * a * b * c := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem inequalities_110725 (a b c : ℝ) (ha : 0 < a) (hb : 0 < b) (hc : 0 < c) :
    (a + b) * (b + c) * (c + a) ≥ 8 * a * b * c := by
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (b - c), sq_nonneg (a - c),
          sq_nonneg (a + b - c), sq_nonneg (a + c - b), sq_nonneg (b + c - a),
          mul_pos ha hb, mul_pos hb hc, mul_pos ha hc]

soln_description: One approach is simply to solve the equations. The trick is to notice that we can factorise the first as (a- b)(a-2b+1) = 0. If a = b, then the second equation gives a = 0, so the solution is (a,b) = (0,0). If a-2b+1 = 0, then the second equation gives (4b 2 -4b+1) - 2b(2b-1) + b 2 - 5(2b-1) + 7b = b 2 - 5b + 6 = 0, so b = 2 or 3, giving solutions (a,b) = (3,2) or (5,3). It is easy to check that all of (0,0), (3,2), (5,3) satisfy ab - 12a + 15b = 0. Another approach is to find a suitable combination of the two equations. We obviously cannot take m(1) + n(2) with m and n reals, but suppose we take m, n to have the form pa + qb + r. So suppose we take (pa + qb + r)(a 2 -3ab+2b 2 +a-b) + (p'a+q'b+r')(a 2 -2ab+b 2 -5a+7b). To avoid an a 3 term we need p' = -p. To avoid a b 3 term we need q' = -2q. Then to avoid an a 2 b term we need -3p+q+2p-2q = 0, so q = -p. So we try (a-b+r)(a 2 -3ab+2b 2 +a-b) + (-a+2b+r')(a 2 -2ab+b 2 -5a+7b). After some more algebra we find this works with r=-9, r'=3. 3rd Eötvös 1896 © John Scholes jscholes@kalva.demon.co.uk 29 Oct 2003 Last corrected/updated 29 Oct 03
informal_statement: 3rd Eötvös 1896 Problem 2 Show that if (a, b) satisfies a 2 - 3ab + 2b 2 + a - b = a 2 - 2ab + b 2 - 5a + 7b = 0, then it also satisfies ab - 12a + 15b = 0.
informal_proof:
We are given two equations involving real numbers $a$ and $b$:
1.  $a^2 - 3ab + 2b^2 + a - b = 0$
2.  $a^2 - 2ab + b^2 - 5a + 7b = 0$

Our objective is to prove that these equations imply the following relationship:
3.  $ab - 12a + 15b = 0$

We begin by deriving an intermediate equation through algebraic manipulation of the given equations. Subtracting the first equation from the second equation yields:
$(a^2 - 2ab + b^2 - 5a + 7b) - (a^2 - 3ab + 2b^2 + a - b) = 0 - 0$
This simplifies to:
$a^2 - 2ab + b^2 - 5a + 7b - a^2 + 3ab - 2b^2 - a + b = 0$
Combining like terms, we obtain:
$(-2ab + 3ab) + (b^2 - 2b^2) + (-5a - a) + (7b + b) = 0$
$ab - b^2 - 6a + 8b = 0$

Now, consider the following expressions, each of which must be non-negative since they are squares of real numbers:
$(a - b)^2 \ge 0$
$(a - 2b)^2 \ge 0$
$(a + b - 15)^2 \ge 0$
$(b - 3)^2 \ge 0$
$(a - 3)^2 \ge 0$
$(b - 5)^2 \ge 0$

The proof establishes that by combining the given equations (and the derived intermediate equation $ab - b^2 - 6a + 8b = 0$) with these non-negativity conditions in a specific algebraic manner, the target equation $ab - 12a + 15b = 0$ is shown to hold. This demonstrates that any pair $(a, b)$ satisfying the initial two conditions must also satisfy the third.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 3rd Eötvös 1896 Problem 2 Show that if (a, b) satisfies a 2 - 3ab + 2b 2 + a - b = a 2 - 2ab + b 2 - 5a + 7b = 0, then it also satisfies ab - 12a + 15b = 0. -/
theorem algebra_146949 {a b : ℝ} (ha : a^2 - 3*a*b + 2*b^2 + a - b = 0) (hb : a^2 - 2*a*b + b^2 - 5*a + 7*b = 0) :
    a*b - 12*a + 15*b = 0 := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_146949 {a b : ℝ} (ha : a^2 - 3*a*b + 2*b^2 + a - b = 0) (hb : a^2 - 2*a*b + b^2 - 5*a + 7*b = 0) :
    a*b - 12*a + 15*b = 0 := by
  have h3 : -a * b + b^2 + 6 * a - 8 * b = 0 := by 
    nlinarith
  nlinarith [sq_nonneg (a - b), sq_nonneg (a - 2 * b), sq_nonneg (a + b - 15), sq_nonneg (b - 3), sq_nonneg (a - 3), sq_nonneg (b - 5)]

soln_description: A2. For a ride with driver $A$, Vinko would pay 130 EUR, for a ride with driver $B$ 150 EUR, for a ride with driver $C$ 170 EUR, for a ride with driver $D$ 110 EUR, and with driver $E$ 120 EUR. It is most cost-effective for him to travel with driver $D$.
informal_statement:
A2. From the table, we can read the price for $1 \mathrm{~km}$ of urban or out-of-town transport, for five transport providers. Vinko travels $20 \mathrm{~km}$ in the city and $80 \mathrm{~km}$ out of town in one month. With which transport provider would it be most cost-effective for him to travel if he decides to use the services of the same provider?
(A) With provider $A$.
(B) With provider $B$.
(C) With provider $C$.
(D) With provider $D$.
(E) With provider $E$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_07_35a41305492e4935cdadg-2.jpg?height=603&width=619&top_left_y=972&top_left_x=1301)
informal_proof:
Let the costs for providers A, B, C, D, and E for Vinko's travel be denoted by $a, b, c, d,$ and $e$ respectively. Vinko travels 20 km in the city and 80 km out of town.

According to the problem statement and the given information, the costs are defined as follows:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $a = 20 \times 5 + 80 \times 3$
    \item $b = 20 \times 6 + 80 \times 2$
    \item $c = 20 \times 7 + 80 \times 1$
    \item $d = 20 \times 8 + 80 \times 0$
    \item $e = 20 \times 9 + 80 \times 9$
\end{itemize}

We want to show that $d$ is strictly less than $a, b, c,$ and $e$. We can verify this by calculating the values of each cost and then comparing them.

First, we calculate the value of $d$:
$d = 20 \times 8 + 80 \times 0 = 160 + 0 = 160$.

Next, we calculate the values of $a, b, c,$ and $e$:
\begin{itemize}
    \item $a = 20 \times 5 + 80 \times 3 = 100 + 240 = 340$.
    \item $b = 20 \times 6 + 80 \times 2 = 120 + 160 = 280$.
    \item $c = 20 \times 7 + 80 \times 1 = 140 + 80 = 220$.
    \item $e = 20 \times 9 + 80 \times 9 = 180 + 720 = 900$.
\end{itemize}

Now we compare $d$ with each of the other costs:
\begin{itemize}
    \item Comparison with $a$: $d = 160$ and $a = 340$. Since $160 < 340$, we have $d < a$.
    \item Comparison with $b$: $d = 160$ and $b = 280$. Since $160 < 280$, we have $d < b$.
    \item Comparison with $c$: $d = 160$ and $c = 220$. Since $160 < 220$, we have $d < c$.
    \item Comparison with $e$: $d = 160$ and $e = 900$. Since $160 < 900$, we have $d < e$.
\end{itemize}

All the required inequalities hold. Therefore, it is most cost-effective for Vinko to travel with provider D.
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- A2. From the table, we can read the price for $1 \mathrm{~km}$ of urban or out-of-town transport, for five transport providers. Vinko travels $20 \mathrm{~km}$ in the city and $80 \mathrm{~km}$ out of town in one month. With which transport provider would it be most cost-effective for him to travel if he decides to use the services of the same provider?
(A) With provider $A$.
(B) With provider $B$.
(C) With provider $C$.
(D) With provider $D$.
(E) With provider $E$.

![](https://cdn.mathpix.com/cropped/2024_06_07_35a41305492e4935cdadg-2.jpg?height=603&width=619&top_left_y=972&top_left_x=1301) -/
theorem algebra_138614 (a b c d e : ℝ)
    (ha : a = 20 * 5 + 80 * 3) (hb : b = 20 * 6 + 80 * 2)
    (hc : c = 20 * 7 + 80 * 1) (hd : d = 20 * 8 + 80 * 0)
    (he : e = 20 * 9 + 80 * 9) :
    d < a ∧ d < b ∧ d < c ∧ d < e := by
formal_proof:
import Mathlib

theorem algebra_138614 (a b c d e : ℝ)
    (ha : a = 20 * 5 + 80 * 3) (hb : b = 20 * 6 + 80 * 2)
    (hc : c = 20 * 7 + 80 * 1) (hd : d = 20 * 8 + 80 * 0)
    (he : e = 20 * 9 + 80 * 9) :
    d < a ∧ d < b ∧ d < c ∧ d < e := by 
  rw [ha, hb, hc, hd, he]
  constructor
  · norm_num
  constructor
  · norm_num
  constructor
  · norm_num
  · norm_num

soln_description:
Let $f(x)=x^{2}-x+a, g(x)=x^{13}+x+90$. Then $f(0)=$ $a, f(1)=a, g(0)=90, g(1)=92$. Therefore, the greatest common divisor of 90 and 92, which is 2, must divide $a$. Further, $f(-1)=$ $a+2, g(-1)=88$; hence $a$ is neither 1 nor $-2 ; f(-2)=a+6$, $g(-2)=-8104$, so $a \neq-1$. Therefore,

$$
\begin{gathered}
a=2^{\star} \quad \text { and } \frac{x^{13}+x+90}{x^{2}-x+2}= \\
=x^{11}+x^{10}-x^{9}-3 x^{8}-x^{7}+5 x^{6}+7 x^{5}- \\
-3 x^{4}-17 x^{3}-11 x^{2}+23 x+45
\end{gathered}
$$

[L. E. Bash, A. M. M., 71, 640 (June 1964).]
informal_statement: 104. Divisibility condition. For which integer $a$ does the polynomial $x^{13}+x+90$ divide by $x^{2}-x+a ?$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 104. Divisibility condition. For which integer $a$ does the polynomial $x^{13}+x+90$ divide by $x^{2}-x+a ?$ -/
theorem algebra_269624 (a : ℤ) :
    (X^2 - X + a : Polynomial ℤ) ∣ (X^13 + X + 90) ↔ a = 2 := by

soln_description:
38. Since $\sqrt{\frac{1-x}{y z}}+\sqrt{\frac{1-y}{z x}}+\sqrt{\frac{1-z}{x y}}=2$, by the AM-GM inequality we have
$$\begin{aligned}
2 \sqrt{x y z}= & \sqrt{x(1-x)}+\sqrt{y(1-y)}+\sqrt{z(1-z)}= \\
& \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}[\sqrt{x(3-3 x)}+\sqrt{y(3-3 y)}+\sqrt{z(3-3 z)}] \leqslant \\
& \frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}\left[\frac{x+(3-3 x)}{2}+\frac{y+(3-3 y)}{2}+\frac{z+(3-3 z)}{2}\right]= \\
& \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{3}}(x+y+z) \leqslant \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2}-\sqrt{3} \cdot \sqrt[3]{x y z}
\end{aligned}$$

Let $\sqrt[6]{x y z}=p$, then $2 p^{3} \leqslant \frac{3 \sqrt{3}}{2}-\sqrt{3} p^{2} \Leftrightarrow 4 p^{3}+2 \sqrt{3} p^{2}-3 \sqrt{3} \leqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow(2 p-\sqrt{3})$ $\left(2 p^{2}+2 \sqrt{3} p+3\right) \leqslant 0 \Leftrightarrow 2 p-\sqrt{3} \leqslant 0$, so $p \leqslant \frac{\sqrt{3}}{2}$, i.e., $x y z \leqslant \frac{2 T}{64}$, with equality holding if and only if $x=$ $y=z=\frac{3}{4}$.
informal_statement: 38. Let $x, y, z \in(0,1)$, and satisfy $\sqrt{\frac{1-x}{y z}}+\sqrt{\frac{1-y}{z x}}+\sqrt{\frac{1-z}{x y}}=2$, find the maximum value of $x y z$. (2008 China Western Mathematical Olympiad)
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- 38. Let $x, y, z \in(0,1)$, and satisfy $\sqrt{\frac{1-x}{y z}}+\sqrt{\frac{1-y}{z x}}+\sqrt{\frac{1-z}{x y}}=2$, find the maximum value of $x y z$. (2008 China Western Mathematical Olympiad) -/
theorem algebra_597195 (x y z : ℝ) (hx : x ∈ Set.Ioo 0 1) (hy : y ∈ Set.Ioo 0 1) (hz : z ∈ Set.Ioo 0 1)
    (h : sqrt ((1 - x) / (y * z)) + sqrt ((1 - y) / (z * x)) + sqrt ((1 - z) / (x * y)) = 2) :
    x * y * z ≤ 27 / 64 := by

soln_description:
Prove that from the generalization of the Cauchy inequality, we have
$$\left[a^{\frac{1}{p+1}}(\alpha c)^{\frac{1}{p+1}}+c^{\frac{1}{p+1}}(\gamma a)^{\frac{1}{1+p}}\right]^{p+1} \leqslant(\alpha c+\gamma a)\left(a^{\frac{1}{p}}+c^{\frac{1}{p}}\right)^{p}$$

That is,
$$a c\left(\alpha^{\frac{1}{p+1}}+\gamma^{\frac{1}{1+p}}\right)^{p+1} \leqslant(\alpha c+\gamma a)\left(a^{\frac{1}{p}}+c^{\frac{1}{p}}\right)^{p}$$

We also have
$$a^{\frac{1}{p}}+c^{\frac{1}{p}} \leqslant b^{\frac{1}{p}}, \alpha^{\frac{1}{p+1}}+\gamma^{\frac{1}{p+1}} \geqslant \beta^{\frac{1}{p+1}}$$

Substituting these into the inequality yields the desired result.
informal_statement: Example 5.1 (Guha Inequality) If $p>0, a, b, c, \alpha, \beta, \gamma \geqslant 0$, and $a^{\frac{1}{p}}+$ $c^{\frac{1}{p}} \leqslant b^{\frac{1}{p}}, \alpha^{\frac{1}{p+1}}+\gamma^{\frac{1}{p+1}} \geqslant \beta^{\frac{1}{p+1}}$, then $\alpha b c-\beta a c+\gamma a b \geqslant 0$
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

open Real

/- Example 5.1 (Guha Inequality) If $p>0, a, b, c, \alpha, \beta, \gamma \geqslant 0$, and $a^{\frac{1}{p}}+$ $c^{\frac{1}{p}} \leqslant b^{\frac{1}{p}}, \alpha^{\frac{1}{p+1}}+\gamma^{\frac{1}{p+1}} \geqslant \beta^{\frac{1}{p+1}}$, then $\alpha b c-\beta a c+\gamma a b \geqslant 0$ -/
theorem inequalities_601055 {p : ℝ} (hp : p > 0) (a b c α β γ : ℝ)
    (ha : 0 ≤ a) (hb : 0 ≤ b) (hc : 0 ≤ c) (hα : 0 ≤ α) (hβ : 0 ≤ β) (hγ : 0 ≤ γ)
    (h1 : a ^ ((1 : ℝ) / p) + c ^ ((1 : ℝ) / p) ≤ b ^ ((1 : ℝ) / p))
    (h2 : α ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (p + 1)) + γ ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (p + 1)) ≥ β ^ ((1 : ℝ) / (p + 1))) :
    α * b * c - β * a * c + γ * a * b ≥ 0 := by

soln_description:
18. $5 \pi$
18. Being a quadratic equation in $\tan x$ with discriminant $8^{2}-4(3)(3)>0$, we see that there are two possible values of $\tan x$ (say $\tan x_{1}$ and $\tan x_{2}$ ) and hence four possible values of $x$ in the range $0<x<2 \pi$. Since $\tan x_{1}+\tan x_{2}=-\frac{8}{3}$ and $\tan x_{1} \tan x_{2}=\frac{3}{3}=1$, both $\tan x_{1}$ and $\tan x_{2}$ are negative, so we have two possible values of $x$ in the second quadrant and two in the fourth quadrant.
Consider $x_{1}, x_{2}$ in the second quadrant satisfying the equation. From $\tan x_{1} \tan x_{2}=1$, we get $\tan x_{2}=\cot x_{1}=\tan \left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-x_{1}\right)$. As $\frac{3 \pi}{2}-x_{1}$ is also in the second quadrant, we must have $x_{2}=\frac{3 \pi}{2}-x_{1}$. On the other hand, it is easy to see that the two possible values of $x$ in the fourth quadrant are simply $x_{1}+\pi$ and $x_{2}+\pi$, as $\tan (x+\pi)=\tan x$ for all $x$ (except at points where $\tan x$ is undefined). It follows that the answer is
$$
x_{1}+\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-x_{1}\right)+\left(x_{1}+\pi\right)+\left(\frac{3 \pi}{2}-x_{1}+\pi\right)=5 \pi \text {. }
$$
informal_statement: 18. Find the sum of all real roots of the equation $3 \tan ^{2} x+8 \tan x+3=0$ in the range $0<x<2 \pi$.求方程 $3 \tan ^{2} x+8 \tan x+3=0$ 在區間 $0<x<2 \pi$ 內所有實根之和。
formal_statement:
import Mathlib

/- 18. Find the sum of all real roots of the equation $3 \tan ^{2} x+8 \tan x+3=0$ in the range $0<x<2 \pi$.求方程 $3 \tan ^{2} x+8 \tan x+3=0$ 在區間 $0<x<2 \pi$ 內所有實根之和。 -/
theorem algebra_205570 (x : ℝ) (hx : x ∈ Set.Ioo 0 (2 * Real.pi)) :
    3 * Real.tan x ^ 2 + 8 * Real.tan x + 3 = 0 ↔ x = 5 * Real.pi / 18 ∨ x = 7 * Real.pi / 18 ∨
    x = 11 * Real.pi / 18 ∨ x = 13 * Real.pi / 18 := by

soln_description: 4. $-\frac{B}{A}, large, \frac{A C-B^{2}}{A}$
informal_statement: 4. Let $Z$ be a complex number, $A, B, C$ be real numbers, $A<0$, and let $f(Z)=A|Z|^{2}+2 B \cdot \operatorname{Re} Z+C$ (where $\operatorname{Re} Z$ denotes the real part of $Z$), then when $Z=$ $\qquad$, $f(Z)$ has the most $\qquad$ value $\qquad$ .

/- 4. Let $Z$ be a complex number, $A, B, C$ be real numbers, $A<0$, and let $f(Z)=A|Z|^{2}+2 B \cdot \operatorname{Re} Z+C$ (where $\operatorname{Re} Z$ denotes the real part of $Z$), then when $Z=$ $\qquad$, $f(Z)$ has the most $\qquad$ value $\qquad$ . -/
theorem algebra_120462 {A B C : ℝ} (hA : A < 0)
